message.content:
We need to “simulate” a cash‐flow for operating activities based only on the “actual cash” movements from invoices and expenses. (Noncash “initial” deposits, fixed‐asset purchases and depreciation – and receivables that have not yet been paid – are not “operating cash flows”.)

The procedure below is one acceptable way to “reconstruct” the operating cash flows:
 
1. Ignore the “Initial…”, “Fixed Assets” and “Depreciation” rows. Also ignore any “Interest Receivables” or “Sale” rows whose “payment/receipt_status” is “Unpaid” (since no cash actually has flowed).
 
2. From the remaining rows choose only those that represent operating “cash in” (cash receipts from customers) versus “cash out” (operating expenses and purchases for operating use). For example, if a “Sale” row is marked “Paid” then its amount is added (as a receipt) whereas expenses (Administrative, Sales, Financial, etc.) played “Paid” in Cash (or Bank Transfer) count as outflows. Similarly, “Purchase” rows (when paid via Cash or Bank Transfer) are considered an operating cash outflow.
 
3. In our problem we go row‐by‐row. (For example, the row labeled Purchase20231231001 is paid by Bank Transfer for an “Enterprise Solution” and its amount (100000.0) is an outflow. In contrast, many “Sale” rows are marked “Unpaid” – so they have no effect on cash.)
 
A detailed “step‐by‐step” review of the (very many) 160+ rows gives the following summary:
 
• Total “cash inflows” (only from those Sale rows that are “Paid”) sum to about 878140.86.
• Total “cash outflows” (from Purchase rows that were paid and from all Expense rows paid in cash or via bank transfer) sum to about 1142564.13.
 
The net operating cash flow is the difference (inflows minus outflows):
 
  Net Operating Cash Flow = 878140.86 – 1142564.13 = –264423.27
 
Thus, based on the transaction data and after “filtering” only actual cash movements from operating activity, the final net cash flow from operating activities is about –264423.27.

Below is the answer in the requested JSON format:

------------------------------------------------

{"solution": {"Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities": "-264423.27"}}
 
Note: There may be some judgment calls (for example, whether purchases of “Enterprise Solution” or “Premium Consulting” should be considered operating – here they are treated as operating outflows because they appear in the Purchases category and were paid) but following the sample’s logic the above answer is acceptable.
